message_1: What is the isotope notation for an atom of carbon-13 and which subatomic particles are different from a typical carbon atom?
message_2:
The isotope notation for an atom of carbon-13 is 13C or alternatively, it can be written as C-13. In this notation, the number 13 represents the mass number (the sum of protons and neutrons) and the letter C represents the element, carbon.

A typical carbon atom, carbon-12 (12C), has 6 protons, 6 neutrons, and 6 electrons. Carbon-13 (13C) also has 6 protons and 6 electrons, but it has 7 neutrons instead of 6. The difference between carbon-12 and carbon-13 lies in the number of neutrons in the nucleus.
